Reproducing an ancient accessibility map as a time cartogram

Matthieu Viry

2025-03-03

Source: vignettes/web_only/reproducing-ancient-map.Rmd
reproducing-ancient-map.Rmd

Introduction

Representing accessibility in cartography is a challenging task. One way of doing this is to use isochrone maps, which are visual representations of which areas you can reach within a given time from one (or sometimes several) starting point(s).

Isochrone map generated on https://classic-maps.openrouteservice.org/


In this type of map, it is common to show areas that can be reached in several given time steps, by coloring these different zones with gradient tints (thus creating what is known in cartography as a choropleth map).

Isochrone map generated on https://classic-maps.openrouteservice.org/


In this vignette, we will use the travel times displayed on an ancient isochrone map from the 19th century in order to create a time cartogram.

Reference map

The reference map we will use is an isochrone map of France showing the travel times by train from Paris in 1882. It is named “Carte des communications rapides entre Paris et le reste de la France” (Map of fast communications between Paris and the rest of France) and was drawn by the French cartographer E. Martin.

It can be viewed in high resolution on the Library of Chicago University.

“Carte des communications rapides entre Paris et le reste de la France”, by E. Martin (1882)


When we zoom in on the map, we can see that the travel times are displayed next to each city name. As indicated on the bottom of the map (in French), the time indicated is in hours and minutes and corresponds to the average between the fastest train journey time from Paris and the fastest train journey time from the town in question to Paris.

Zoom in E. Martin’s map


For example, the travel time for Saint-Brieuc reads 10h30 so we will store 630 minutes in the dataset we are creating.

Data extraction

The first step is to extract the travel times from the map.

Due to the nature of the document, we’ll have to extract them manually (an OCR extraction was tested but didn’t give satisfactory results). In addition, the map includes many cities, but we’re going to concentrate here on the main ones to make the exercise easier.

We will therefore enter the data in a CSV file, using the following format (the first line is the list of cities, the first column is the list of cities, and the other cells contain the travel times in minutes):

csv_data <- ",PARIS,LILLE,DIEPPE,CHERBOURG-EN-COTENTIN,ROUEN,SAINT-BRIEUC,REIMS,NANCY,BREST,RENNES,LE MANS,CHAUMONT,EPINAL,TOURS,QUIMPER,VANNES,DIJON,BESANCON,LA ROCHE-SUR-YON,LA ROCHELLE,CLERMONT-FERRAND,LYON,ALBERTVILLE,GRENOBLE,RODEZ,BORDEAUX,TOULOUSE,HENDAYE,FOIX,PERPIGNAN,MARSEILLE,NICE
PARIS,0,250,240,535,160,630,180,395,825,450,240,255,575,350,970,765,345,510,490,530,525,530,895,815,880,545,850,1015,1170,1100,935,1410"

data <- read.csv(text = csv_data)

Data import
